Journal.Title: Biochemistry and cell biology = Biochimie et biologie cellulaire

Article.ArticleTitle: Beneficial effects of nontoxic ozone on H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>-induced stress and inflammation.

AbstractText: In this study, the anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory efficacy of ozone oxidative preconditioning (OOP) were investigated on hydrogen peroxide (H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>)-induced human lung alveolar cells. In MTT and trypan blue viability tests, while 100 μmol/L H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> caused a 17.3% and 21.9% decrease in the number of living cells, respectively, ozone at 20 μmol/L regenerated cell proliferation and prevented 9.6% and 11.0% of cell loss, respectively. In addition, H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> decreased the transcription levels of catalase (CAT), glutathione peroxidase (GPx), and superoxide dismutase (SOD) 5.43-, 2.89-, and 5.33-fold, respectively, while it increased Bax, NF-κβ, TNF-α, and iNOS expression 1.57-, 1.32-, 1.40-, and 1.41-fold, respectively. Ozone pretreatment, however, increased CAT, GPx, and SOD transcription levels 7.08-, 5.17-, and 6.49-fold and decreased Bax, NF-κβ, TNF-α, and iNOS transcriptions by 1.25-, 0.76-, 3.63-, and 7.91-fold, respectively. Moreover, intracellular glutathione (GSH) level and SOD activity were decreased by 46.2% and 45.0% in the H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> treatment group, and OOP recovered 58.5% and 20.1% of the decreases caused by H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>. H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> also increased nitrite levels 7.84-fold, and OOP reduced this increase by half. Consequently, OOP demonstrated potent anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory effects on in vitro model of oxidative stress-induced lung injury.
